title: In Nationals’ clincher, Max Scherzer’s uneven outing offers more questions than answers
text:
Deal them in: Nats sweep Phillies in doubleheader, clinch NL wild-card spot

Trea Turner proved that wasn’t the case, and his sixth-inning grand slam gave the Nationals the lead for good in what became a 6-5 win in the second stanza of a day-night doubleheader. The victory clinched a postseason berth because, while Washington rallied, the Pittsburgh Pirates improbably did, too; the Pirates snapped a nine-game losing streak by beating the Chicago Cubs, 9-2.

The Nationals will play in the wild-card game on the first day of October. That fact, for a moment, overwhelmed everything. Scherzer, in the clubhouse after the game, snapped on swimming goggles and sprayed everyone in sight with a bottle of Campo Viejo.

“We’re good,” he said. “We’re a good freakin’ team. And we can play with anybody in this league.”

Then, slowly, the situation came back into focus. The Milwaukee Brewers are one step away from securing their spot as the wild-card opponent. Two serious questions remain: Will the game be in Milwaukee or Washington? And will Scherzer start?

The former is tough to say with five games left and the Nationals leading the Brewers by one game. The latter seemed clear Tuesday when Martinez intimated yes.

“If you look at the schedule right now, that’s Max’s day,” the manager said. “And he’s one of the best.”

Boswell: The Nats earned their spot in the postseason, but they still have unfinished business

Yet the 35-year-old’s hiccups raised doubts because the other candidate, Stephen Strasburg, is as durable and dominant as ever. Strasburg is scheduled to start Thursday, putting him on regular rest for next Tuesday while Scherzer is lined up to pitch Sunday and could if Game 162 decides home field. Strasburg’s track record in the postseason — one earned run in 19 innings across three starts — bests Scherzer’s (a 3.73 ERA in 16 appearances).

Scherzer’s results Tuesday — four runs on five hits in six innings — were more concerning because he seemed in prime position to dominate. The Phillies’ starting lineup was without their three best hitters: Bryce Harper, J.T. Realmuto and Rhys Hoskins.

Things went wrong right away. Scherzer walked the second hitter, and the third reached on an infield hit before Miller crushed a 425-foot shot to center. The infamously fiery starter betrayed no more frustration than stalking around the mound.

Perhaps the most frustrating part for Scherzer was that his stuff still seemed strong. He tallied 10 strikeouts — his 11th double-digit total of the season — before departing. He proved it right away, too, escaping the first by striking out both batters after Miller, the first on a slider and the second on a change-up. He insisted he felt good and said that, even compared with his previous start against the St. Louis Cardinals, he felt stronger after 90 pitches.

“I feel sharp,” he said. “I feel like I’m really built for 100 pitches right now. I feel like I’m still ­executing better than ever.”

Game 1: Nats eliminate Phillies from playoff contention, move closer to clinching spot of their own

Scherzer retired the next six hitters — including three on strikeouts. Then he ran into Miller again. The 29-year-old journeyman entered Tuesday a career .239 hitter with 83 homers in ­seven seasons. He had found some success against Scherzer before — he was 3 for 7 with a homer and a double coming into the game — but what he did next seemed improbable at best: Miller rocked a Scherzer two-seamer deep to right field for a solo shot.

The starter exited after 101 pitches, but reliever Daniel Hudson said he was convinced Scherzer would’ve pitched the seventh had his spot in the order not come up.

“I feel really good about going forward in the playoffs,” Scherzer said.

Not everyone else can say the same. It didn’t matter that Scherzer retired nine of his last 11 hitters. It didn’t matter for the night’s final score. It didn’t matter that no one else generated solid contact the way Miller had. Those two mistakes still meant Scherzer left the mound with more questions than answers.
description: Scherzer is lined up to pitch in the National League wild-card game, but he hasn’t looked like his dominant self recently.
